0: Japanese-American senator hits Zinke over ‘flippant’ response on preserving internment sites NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Sen. Mazie Hirono (D-Hawaii) on Thursday called it “flippant & juvenile” for Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke to respond to a question about preserving internment sites with a Japanese greeting. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “The internment of nearly 120,000 Japanese Americans is no laughing matter, @SecretaryZinke,” tweeted Hirono, the first U.S. senator born in Japan and the first Asian-American woman elected to the chamber. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Story Continued Below NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR During a House Natural Resources Committee hearing earlier in the day, Zinke was pressed by Rep. Colleen Hanabusa (D-Hawaii), a fourth-generation Japanese-American, to commit to refunding a National Park Service program that offers grants toward the preservation of confinement camps where Japanese-Americans were held during World War II. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Are you committed to continue to grant programs that are identified, I believe, as the Japanese American Confinement Sites grants program which were funded in 2017? Will we see them funded again in 2018?” Hanabusa asked. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Oh, konnichiwa,” Zinke replied, deploying a Japanese greeting typically used in midday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR After a brief silence, Hanabusa corrected Zinke, using the Japanese greeting for “good morning.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I think it’s still ‘ohayo gozaimasu,’ but that‘s OK,” she said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “What you thought was a clever response to @RepHanabusa was flippant & juvenile,” Hirono wrote on Twitter. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR After the brief exchange at the hearing, Zinke said funding for the grants “probably got caught up” by larger 2018 budgetary items, and vowed to work with Hanabusa on the matter. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I will look at it and I will work with you on it because I think it is important,” Zinke told her. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Hanabusa, who said her two grandparents were subjected to internment, framed the program as a necessity during the hearing.
